evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted by standard procedures from blood samples and was analyzed by PCR amplification and direct sequencing of RMRP.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage hair hypoplasia is an autosomal recessive type of metaphyseal chondrodysplasia, caused by mutations in the ribonuclease mitochondrial RNA processing (RMRP) gene. Typical features of cartilage hair hypoplasia include short stature, a predisposition to malignancy, and a variable degree of impairment of cellular immunity.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kavadas FD
dc:source.dc:title: Variability of clinical and laboratory features among patients with ribonuclease mitochondrial RNA processing endoribonuclease gene mutations.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 4

evidence.dc:description:
The RMRP n.-7_1dupAGGACGTG variant involves the duplication of 8 nucleotides in the promoter region/transcriptional start-site of RMRP. The variant allele was found at a frequency of 0.00017 in 128228 control chromosomes (gnomAD). This duplication variant has been reported in the literature in individuals affected with CHH (Bonafe_2005, Kavadas_2008). Several laboratories have reported functional studies suggesting that other insertion/duplication mutations in the promoter region of RMRP silence transcription (e.g. Ridanpaa_2001, Hermanns_2005). 
The n.71A>G (noncoding transcript variant; legacy name 70A>G) variant is a common pathogenic founder mutation. The variant allele was found at a frequency of 0.00087 in 130486 control chromosomes (gnomAD). This variant has been reported in the literature in multiple homozygous and compound heterozygous individuals affected with CHH(PMIDs 11207361, 1915-6-6). n.71A>G has been reported to impair cleavage of both 5.8S rRNA and cyclin B2 mRNA in the literature (e.g. Hermanns_2005, Thiel_2007).

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA from a fibroblast cell line established from the patient's cells were extracted using standard methods. The whole RNA coding region of RMRP was amplified by PCR, then sequenced.

dc:source.dc:creator: Kuijpers TW
dc:source.dc:title: Short-limbed dwarfism with bowing, combined immune deficiency, and late onset aplastic anaemia caused by novel mutations in the RMPR gene.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband Kuijpers

evidence.dc:description:
Patient is compound heterozygous for two mutations in the RMRP transcript, 63C>T (maternally inherited) and insT195 (paternally inherited). The insT195 sequence change has been reported as compound heterozygous with another RMRP variant in individuals affected with RMRP-related conditions (PMID: 14569125, 16838329). Many other insertions or duplications in the promoter region of RMRP have been reported in affected individuals in the literature (e.g. PMIDs: 21956908, 21396580) and have been demonstrated through functional studies to lead to reduced RMRP transcription (e.g. PMIDs: 11207361, 16254002)
The RMRP n.64C>T (also known as n.63C>T) variant involves the alteration of a conserved nucleotide. The variant allele was found was found at a frequency of 2.4e-05 in 125614 control chromosomes (gnomAD). n.64C>T has been reported in the literature in homozygote and compound heterozygote individuals affected with CHH (Bonafe_2005, Bordon_2010, Ridanpaa_2002). Both mutations reside in evolutionarily conserved nucleotides and were not found in healthy controls.

evidence.detectionMethod: Compound heterozygosity for a 13bp duplication in the promotor (g.-26_-14 dup TACTACTCTGTGA) inherited from mother, and a nucleotide substitution (g.4C>T) close to the transcription initiation site inherited form father.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report a child with short stature since birth who was otherwise well, presenting at 2.8 years with progressive granulomatous skin lesions when diagnosed with severe T cell immunodeficiency. When previously investigated for short stature, and at the time of current investigations, she had no radiological skeletal features characteristics for cartilage hair hypoplasia, but we found a disease causing RMRP (RNase mitochondrial RNA processing endoribonuclease) gene mutation. Whilst search for HLA matched unrelated donor for haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) was underway, she developed rapidly progressive EBV-related lymphoproliferative disorder requiring laparotomy and small bowel resection, and was treated with anti-B cell monoclonal antibody and eventually curative allogeneic HSCT. Screening for RMRP gene mutations should be part of immunological evaluation of patients with 'severe and/or combined' T cell immunodeficiency of unknown origin, especially when associated with short stature and regardless of presence or absence of radiological skeletal features.
dc:source.dc:creator: McCann LJ
dc:source.dc:title: Phenotypic variations of cartilage hair hypoplasia: granulomatous skin inflammation and severe T cell immunodeficiency as initial clinical presentation in otherwise well child with short stature.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband

evidence.dc:description:
The RMRP n.5C>T (also known as n.4C>T) variant has been reported in the literature in multiple other individuals affected with CHH (PMIDs: 17015150, 20375313, 16838329, 18804272, 16244706). This variant has been reported to affect RMRP activity, causing CHH, as shown in PMID 17701897.
The g.-26_-14dup sequence change (13 nucleotide insertion) is also known as g.-25_-13dup in the literature. This variant has been observed in combination with other RMRP variants in individuals affected with RMRP-related diseases (PMID: 21396580). In addition, this variant is located in the promoter region between the TATA box and the transcription initiation site, and other similar insertions and duplications immediately upstream of the coding sequence have been reported in individuals affected with cartilage-hair hypoplasia (PMID: 11207361, 16838329, 17189938, 21570718, 21396580).

evidence.detectionMethod: Amplification and sequencing of DNA sequence containing the RMRP gene with the promotor region. Sequencing analysis revealed a novel homozygous mutation which is a duplication of 7 NTs at position -19 from the transcription initiation site (g.-19_-25dupACTACTC).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH) is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder characterized by short-limbed dwarfism, sparse hair, and immune deficiency. It is caused by mutations in the RMRP gene, which encodes the RNA component of the mitochondrial RNA-processing ribonuclease (RNase MRP). Several mutations have been identified in its promoter region or transcribed sequence. However, homozygous mutations in the promoter region have been only reported in a patient with primary immunodeficiency without other features of CHH. We report on a Thai girl who first presented with chronic diarrhea, recurrent pneumonia, and severe failure to thrive, without apparently disproportionate dwarfism. The diagnosis of CHH was made after the severe wasting was corrected, and disproportionate growth became noticeable. The patient had the typical features of CHH, including sparse hair and metaphyseal abnormalities. The immunologic profiles were consistent with combined immune deficiency. Mutation analysis identified a novel homozygous mutation, g.-19_-25 dupACTACTC, in the promoter region of the RMRP gene. Identification of the mutation enabled us to provide a prenatal diagnosis in the subsequent pregnancy. This patient is the first CHH case with the characteristic features due to the homozygous mutation in the promoter region of the RMRP gene. The finding of severe immunodeficiency supports that promoter mutations markedly disrupt mRNA cleavage function, which causes cell-cycle impairment.
dc:source.dc:creator: Vatanavicharn N
dc:source.dc:title: An infant with cartilage-hair hypoplasia due to a novel homozygous mutation in the promoter region of the RMRP gene associated with chondrodysplasia and severe immunodeficiency.

evidence.rdfs:label: Thai Patient

evidence.dc:description: RMRP n.-24_-18dupACTACTC involves the duplication of seven nucleotides in the promoter region of the RMRP gene which is located between the TATA box (at position -33 to -25) and the transcription initiation site (at +1). This variant is also known as g.-19_-25dupACTACTC in the literature. No experimental evidence demonstrating an impact on protein function has been reported for this specific variant. Many other insertions or duplications in the promoter region of RMRP have been reported in affected individuals in the literature (e.g. PMIDs: 21956908, 21396580) and have been demonstrated through functional studies to lead to reduced RMRP transcription (e.g. PMIDs: 11207361, 16254002). The paper was scored at a 1.5 points given there was no evidence for this specific insertion variant.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood leukocytes. The entire transcribed region and ~225-bp promotor region of the RMRP gene was amplified by PCR and screens for mutations through direct sequencing.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH), or McKusick type metaphyseal chondrodysplasia, was first recognized as a distinct entity in the Old Order Amish in the USA, but was later identified in other groups, and found to be unusually frequent among Finns. CHH is highly pleiotropic with manifestations that include short stature, defective cellular immunity and predisposition to several cancers. CHH is caused by mutations in the RNA component of RNase MRP (RMRP, ribonuclease mitochondrial RNA processing) and is transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait. In the present work, a Spanish CHH patient was extensively characterized at the immunological and molecular DNA level. Several parameters of cellular and humoral immunity were analyzed in this patient: lymphocyte subpopulation, proliferative responsiveness in mitogen stimulation and quantification of serum immunoglobulins. Sequencing of the RMRP gene allowed identification of two mutations in the patient: a +4 C>T substitution previously described on one allele, and a duplication of 15 nucleotides at position -11 on the other allele. This mutation has not previously been described.
dc:source.dc:creator: Muñoz-Robles J
dc:source.dc:title: A novel RMRP mutation in a Spanish patient with cartilage-hair hypoplasia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband

evidence.dc:description: The patient has compound heterozygous mutations: +4C>T (paternally inherited) and g.-25_-11dupACTACTCTGTGAAGC (maternally inherited). The variant (g.-25_-11dupACTACTCTGTGAAGC) has been observed in other individuals with CHH (PMIDs: 25616543, 11207361). This variant is located in the promoter region between the TATA box and the transcription initiation site. Experimental analyses using patient-derived cells from patients with RMRP promoter variants, as well as in vitro transfection studies, have shown that these promoter insertions result in silencing of RMRP transcription and reduced expression of the gene product (PMID: 11207361, 16254002). The RMRP n.5C>T (also known as n.4C>T) variant has been reported in the literature in multiple other individuals affected with Cartilage-Hair Hypoplasia (PMIDs: 20375313, 16838329, 18804272, 16244706). This variant has been reported to affect RMRP activity, causing CHH, as shown in PMID 17701897.

evidence.detectionMethod: Molecular diagnosis was uncovered by linkage analyses performed on all members of the family which had identified a 46 Mb region containing around 426 genes. Sanger sequencing confirmed the homozygous mutations (35C>A) within RMRP gene.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in RMRP primarily give rise to Cartilage Hair Hypoplasia (CHH), a highly diverse skeletal disorder which can be associated with severe immunodeficiency. Increased availability of RMRP mutation screening has uncovered a number of infants with significant immunodeficiency but only mild or absent skeletal features. We surveyed the clinical and immunological phenotype of children who have undergone allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation for this condition in the UK.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ip W
dc:source.dc:title: Variable phenotype of severe immunodeficiencies associated with RMRP gene mutations.

evidence.rdfs:label: P3

evidence.dc:description: 36C>A occurs in the untranslated RMRP gene. Other compound heterozygous variants (in association with 70A>G mutation) in this nucleotide have been pathogenic which further suggests that disruption of this nucleotide is determined to be significant. (PMID: 16244706, 18164267). The affected P3 domain is critical for RMRP binding to protein subunits and nucleolar localization. For these reasons and in addition, the variant being confirmed homozygous, this was scored as 0.25.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia is a short limbed skeletal dysplasia associated with impairments in host-defense. To better understand the clinical heterogeneity of this disorder, we studied 25 Amish patients with homozygous mutations in RMRP (RMRP 70 A>G). Despite mutation homogeneity, eight (32%) patients had severe or recurrent infections, two (8%) of these children underwent bone-marrow transplantation for combined immunodeficiency, and the remainder were healthy. Features distinguishing patients who underwent bone marrow transplantation from others were shorter birth length, and lower serum IgG, undetectable serum IgA, and elevated circulating NK cells before 2 years of age. Irrespective of clinical phenotype, most patients had lymphopenia and reduced lymphocyte proliferation to mitogens in vitro. Our cohort analysis suggests that many patients with cartilage-hair hypoplasia are at risk for infection susceptibility particularly during the first 2 years of life. Gauging this risk is difficult, and thus careful monitoring of all patients with cartilage-hair hypoplasia is warranted.
dc:source.dc:creator: Rider NL
dc:source.dc:title: Immunologic and clinical features of 25 Amish patients with RMRP 70 A-->G cartilage hair hypoplasia.

evidence.dc:description: RMRP n.71A>G (legacy name 70A>G) is a pathogenic founder mutation that occurs in multiple populations. This is a well-described founder mutation with a low variant allele frequency amongst healthy controls (GnomAD), and is located in a sequence element that is highly conserved across species. Functional analysis of this specific variant has been associated with reduced RNA cleavage activity and abnormal ribosomal processing (PMID: 17701897). n.71A>G has been reported in the literature in multiple homozygous and compound heterozygous individuals affected with CHH (PMID 11207361, 21570718, 16254002).

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted and analyzed by PCR amplification and direct sequencing of the RMRP gene.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH) is characterized by metaphyseal dysplasia, bone marrow failure, increased risk of malignancies, and a variable degree of immunodeficiency. CHH is caused by mutations in the RNA component of the mitochondrial RNA processing (RMRP) endoribonuclease gene, which is involved in ribosomal assembly, telomere function, and cell cycle control.
dc:source.dc:creator: de la Fuente MA
dc:source.dc:title: Reduced thymic output, cell cycle abnormalities, and increased apoptosis of T lymphocytes in patients with cartilage-hair hypoplasia.

evidence.rdfs:label: P17

evidence.dc:description:
The patient is homozygous for g.27G>A. No information on parental inheritance was provided. Functional expression studies described in this paper show that this patient has markedly reduced recent thymic emigrants (RTEs), T lymphopenia, defects in cell cycle control and increased apoptosis demonstrating that RMRP mutations have an effect on lymphocyte maturation and function, as well as interference of thymus generation of T lymphocytes. 
This paper was scored at 0.1 because there is no specific evidence that this variant has a deleterious effect, and there is insufficient evidence to confirm homozygosity.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral leukocytes. The entire transcribed region and ~115bp of the promoter region of the human RMRP were amplified by PCR and screens for mutations by direct sequencing.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH) is an autosomal recessive disorder which is characterized by bone metaphysis anomalies with manifestations that include short stature, defective cellular immunity, and predisposition to several cancers. It is caused by mutations in RMRP, which is transcribed as an RNA component of the mitochondrial RNA-processing ribonuclease. We report the clinical and molecular data of a Moroccan patient with CHH. Sequencing of RMRP identified 2 mutations in the patient: the known mutation g.97G>A and the variation g.27G>C, which has not been reported previously. Given the high mutational heterogeneity, the high frequency of variations in the region, and the fact that RMRP is a non-coding gene, assigning the pathogenicity to RMRP mutations remains a difficult task. Therefore, we compared the characteristics of the primary and secondary structures of mutated RMRP sequences. The location of our mutations within the secondary structure of the RMRP molecule revealed that the novel g.27G>C mutation causes a disruption in the Watson-Crick base pairing, which results in an impairment of a highly conserved P3 domain. Our work prompts considering the consequences of novel RMRP nucleotide variations on conserved RNA structures to gain insights into the pathogenicity of mutations.
dc:source.dc:creator: Cherkaoui Jaouad I
dc:source.dc:title: Novel Mutation and Structural RNA Analysis of the Noncoding RNase MRP Gene in Cartilage-Hair Hypoplasia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Moroccan girl

evidence.dc:description:
The g.97G>A variant (maternally inherited) has been observed in combination with another RMRP variant in several individuals affected with RMRP-related conditions (PMID: 16838329, 16244706, 32021596). The variant is also known as g.98G>A in the literature. 
The g.27G>C variant is located in the RMRP transcript. Furthermore, this variant was not found in 50 healthy Moroccan individuals that were assessed as controls. Simulation of RNA folding to analyze mutational consequences in structure showed that this missense variation (g.27G>C) compromised formation of the small 46-bp-long hairpin structure.

RNase MRP NRA expression was found in all CHH patients, however, it was less abundantly present in patients 7 & 8 (both compound heterozygotes) compared to controls. Quantitative analysis using a phosphorimager showed that level of expression of RNase MRP RNA in patients 7 & 8 was reduced to 35-40% compared to control.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The recessively inherited developmental disorder, cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH) is highly pleiotropic with manifestations including short stature, defective cellular immunity, and predisposition to several cancers. The endoribonuclease RNase MRP consists of an RNA molecule bound to several proteins. It has at least two functions, namely, cleavage of RNA in mitochondrial DNA synthesis and nucleolar cleaving of pre-rRNA. We describe numerous mutations in the untranslated RMRP gene that cosegregate with the CHH phenotype. Insertion mutations immediately upstream of the coding sequence silence transcription while mutations in the transcribed region do not. The association of protein subunits with RNA appears unaltered. We conclude that mutations in RMRP cause CHH by disrupting a function of RNase MRP RNA that affects multiple organ systems.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ridanpää M
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in the RNA component of RNase MRP cause a pleiotropic human disease, cartilage-hair hypoplasia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Northern blot of RNase MRP RNA Expression

evidence.dc:description: Patient 8 is of German descent, has compound heterozygous variants in 70A>G (paternally inherited) and insCCTGAG at -6 (maternally inherited). RMRP n.71A>G (noncoding transcript variant; legacy name 70A>G) is a common pathogenic founder mutation. It has been reported in the literature in multiple homozygous and compound heterozygous individuals affected with CHH, and has been reported to impair cleavage of both 5.8S rRNA and cyclin B2 mRNA in the literature (e.g. Hermanns_2005, Thiel_2007). The second variant is a 6bp insertion at position -6. Experimental evidence shows that quantitative analysis using a phosphorimager showed that level of expression of RNase MRP RNA in patients 8 (and patient 7, not included) was reduced to 35-40% compared to control.

RMRP RNA expression is reduced in 3 patients with CHH compared to healthy controls. Patient 2 is compound heterozygous for 89C>G, 124C>T. Patient 8 is homozygous for 70A>G base pair substitution. Patient 16 is compound heterozygous for promoter duplication -14_-23dup and the BP substitution 180G>A. RMRP RNA level in leukocytes is approximately 6 to 7-fold down-regulated in CHH patients compared to six healthy controls.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cartilage-hair hypoplasia (CHH), also known as metaphyseal chondrodysplasia McKusick type (OMIM no. 250250), is an autosomal recessive, multi-systemic disease characterized by disproportionate short stature, fine and sparse hair, deficient cellular immunity and a predisposition to malignancy. It is caused by mutations in RMRP, the RNA component of the ribonucleoprotein complex RNase MRP, and, thus, CHH represents one of few Mendelian disorders caused by mutations in a nuclear encoded, non-coding RNA. While studies in yeast indicate that RMRP contributes to diverse cellular functions, the pathogenesis of the human condition is unknown. Studies of our CHH patient cohort revealed mutations in both the promoter and the transcribed region of RMRP. While mutations in the promoter abolished transcription in vitro, RMRP RNA levels in patients with transcribed mutations were also decreased suggesting an unstable RNA. RMRP mutations introduced into the yeast ortholog, NME1, exhibited normal mitochondrial function, chromosomal segregation and cell cycle progression, while a CHH fibroblast cell line exhibited normal mitochondrial content. However, the most commonly found mutation in CHH patients, 70A>G, caused an alteration in ribosomal processing by altering the ratio of the short versus the long form of the 5.8S rRNA in yeast. Transcriptional profiling of CHH patient RNAs showed upregulation of several cytokines and cell cycle regulatory genes, one of which has been implicated in chondrocyte hypertrophy. These data suggest that alteration of ribosomal processing in CHH is associated with altered cytokine signalling and cell cycle progression in terminally differentiating cells in the lymphocytic and chondrocytic cell lineages.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hermanns P
dc:source.dc:title: Consequences of mutations in the non-coding RMRP RNA in cartilage-hair hypoplasia.

evidence.rdfs:label: RMRP Expression Level

evidence.dc:description:
RMRP RNA expression is reduced in 3 patients with CHH compared to healthy controls. Patient 8 (variant scored) is homozygous for 70A>G base pair substitution. Patient 2 is compound heterozygous for 89C>G, 124C>T. Patient 16 is compound heterozygous for promoter duplication -14_-23dup and the BP substitution 180G>A. RMRP RNA level in leukocytes is approximately 6 to 7-fold down-regulated in CHH patients compared to six healthy controls.
Thought patients 2 and 16 (compound heterozygotes) also demonstrated down regulation of RMRP RNA expression, only patient 8 was scored due to lack of confirmation that particular variants were in trans.
Both absolute and relative numbers of RTEs were significantly reduced compared to control.
evidence.rdfs:label: RTEs

evidence.dc:description: Immunohistochemistry of the thymus and mediastinal lymph node. Thymus was stained for anti-TdT, showing a disturbed architecture with loss of demarcation between cortex and medulla, scattered TdT+ cells in central area of thymus lobule and absent Hassal's bodies. A mediastinal lymph node was stained for anti-IgG showing a partial lymphocyte depletion of the paracortical areas, which were small and contained only a few CD3+ T cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunohistochemistry of thymus and mediastinal lymph node

dc:description: RMRP was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive cartilage-hair hypoplasia in 2001 (Ridanpaa et al, PMID: 11207361). The phenotype of CHH patients can be variable but may include: shortened limbs, short stature, metaphysical dysplasia, fine, sparse and/or light-colored hair, hematologic abnormalities and a spectrum of combined immunodeficiency. RMRP encodes an untranslated RNA component of mitochondrial RNA processing endoribonuclease that is critical for DNA replication; defective RMRP functioning ultimately impairs cell proliferation and differentiation. Over 130 variants (insertions, duplications and missense variations) have been reported in numerous publications (PMIDs: 11207361, 14569125, 16254002, 17015150, 18978468, 19150606, 21063072, 21570718, 25663137, 28094436, 28126377) and many are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is reported to be loss of function. Heterozygous carriers have not been shown to have a clinical phenotype. This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence, PMIDs 20133615, 24889605, 10911993, 18804272). In summary, RMRP is definitively associated with autosomal recessive cartilage-hair hypoplasia. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.
